recordNew.card.aerobic.title: Aerobic Fitness / Target HR
recordNew.card.ohs.title: Overhead Squat Test
recordNew.card.posture.title: Static Posture Analysis
recordNew.card.sitReach.title: Sit and Reach Test
recordNew.card.strength.title: Strength Tests
recordNew.card.tanita.bmi.tip: This is the BMI value shown directly on the Tanita device. No manual calculation is needed.
recordNew.card.tanita.tip: All values in this section are objective measurements from the Tanita body composition analyzer. For best accuracy, the client should be measured on an empty stomach, at similar times, and preferably under the same conditions. Values should be interpreted over time and evaluated based on trends.
recordNew.card.tanita.title: Physical Measurements (Tanita)
recordNew.card.tape.title: Circumference Measurements (Tape)
recordNew.field.ohsLowBackArch: Does the low back arch excessively?
recordNew.field.ymcaPulse: YMCA 3-min Step Test — Recovery Heart Rate
recordNew.help.bruce: Bruce test protocol: Treadmill speed and incline increase every 3 minutes; record the final time the client can sustain.
recordNew.help.hasPain: Ongoing pain in areas such as low back, knee, shoulder?
recordNew.help.hadSurgery: Orthopedic or other surgery in recent years.
recordNew.tip.carvonen: The Carvonen method uses resting heart rate and age to calculate target exercise heart rate. The selected zone determines training intensity (fat loss, endurance, performance, etc.).
recordNew.tip.quickScan: Quick Scan: The three items below help quickly classify observed compensation patterns. If you’re unsure, you can select “No” or add details in the notes field.
recordNew.tip.recordNotes: Shown on the student info screen.
recordNew.tip.restingHr: Resting heart rate should be measured immediately after waking up, before getting out of bed. In individuals who exercise regularly, it tends to decrease over time and is an important indicator of cardiovascular fitness.
recordNew.tip.targetHr: The calculated target heart rate indicates the recommended beats per minute to reach during exercise. Staying within this range supports progress aligned with the workout goal.
recordNew.tip.ymca: The post-exercise recovery heart rate measured after the YMCA 3-minute step test is used to evaluate aerobic capacity and how quickly the heart returns to normal after exercise.
recordNew.tip.ymcaResult: YMCA test results indicate aerobic fitness level by age and sex. A lower recovery heart rate generally reflects better cardiovascular conditioning.
recordNew.tip.bruceNote: Note: The treadmill should be set to km/h; incline is entered as a percentage.
